qas.question: Who first discovered the basic properties of capacitors?
When were the basic properties of capacitors first discovered?
In the original experiment in which the properties of capacitors were discovered, what component acted as the dielectric?
Besides the scientist's hand, what other component of the experiment in which the basic properties of capacitors were discovered acted as the second conductor?
What was the name of the Dutch physicist who invented the Leyden Jar?
Who did not discover the basic properties of capacitors?

plausible_answers.text: Ewald Georg von Kleist of Pomerania, Germany, found that charge could be stored

qas.question: In the original experiment in which the properties of capacitors were discovered, what component didn't act as the dielectric?
What was the name of the French physicist who invented the Leyden Jar?
Who said: "I would take a second shock for the kingdom of France."

context: <a1_0>In October 1745<a1_0/>, <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>Ewald Georg von Kleist<b5_0/><a0_0/> of Pomerania, Germany, found that charge could be stored<b6_0/> by connecting a high-voltage electrostatic generator by a wire to a volume of water in <a2_0>a <b7_0>hand-held glass jar<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Von Kleist's hand and <a3_0>the water acted as conductors<a3_0/>, and the jar as a dielectric (although details of the mechanism were incorrectly identified at the time). Von Kleist found that touching the wire resulted in a powerful spark, much more painful than that obtained from an electrostatic machine. The following year, the Dutch physicist <a4_0><b8_0><b9_0>Pieter van Musschenbroek<b9_0/><b8_0/><a4_0/> invented a similar capacitor, which was named the Leyden jar, after the University of Leiden where he worked. He also was impressed by the power of the shock he received, writing, "I would not take a second shock for the kingdom of France."
